awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Effects of Post-translational Modifications and Histone Variants on Chromatin Fiber Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
In plants and animals, DNA is packaged and maintained in chromatin fibers. These structures are comprised of nucleosomes, which are made up of nucleic acid molecules wrapped around proteins called histones.  Chromatin remodeling factors alter the nucleosome, thereby regulating the overall structure and stability of chromatin fibers, and modulating gene expression. In this project, the effects of two major classes of chromatin remodeling factors will be addressed with state-of-the-art computer simulations. These studies will reveal the physical basis by which cells modulate the structure and dynamics of chromosomes, and how this affects the vital process of gene expression. This project will also expose students throughout the educational system to cutting-edge biophysics research. Introductory and advanced courses will be developed that transcend traditional scientific boundaries and undergraduate and pre-and post-doctoral students will receive hands-on training. This project will increase participation in research for students from underrepresented groups, educate future middle and high school teachers, and provide training to the next generation of scientists. 

Eukaryotes package and maintain their genetic code in chromatin fibers. The fundamental unit of these structures is the nucleosome, a complex of eight histone proteins that wrap ~147 base pairs of DNA. By altering the biochemical properties of the nucleosome, the cell regulates the structure and stability of chromatin and thus influences gene expression. Two of the primary mechanisms by which this occurs are post-translational modifications of histone residues and replacement of canonical histones with histone variants.  The effects of these chromatin remodeling factors on the structures and stabilities of nucleosomes have been extensively studied. However, it is only in recent years that it has become evident that chromatin exhibits significant conformational dynamics, the details of which, and how remodeling factors influences them, remain elusive. The goal of this project is to determine how post-translational modifications and histone variants affect intra- and inter-nucleosome dynamics as a means of regulating gene expression. This project will test the hypothesis that chromatin remodeling factors function by creating local perturbations that propagate through allosteric networks to induce global changes in nucleosomes and chromatin fibers. To do this, biomolecular simulations will be performed to address (1) how the local effects of post-translational modifications at dynamic hotspots influence global structures and dynamics, and (2) how the effects of histone variants propagate through inter-nucleosomal dynamical networks into chromatin fibers. This will be done with all-atom and coarse-grain molecular dynamics simulations, and will utilize conventional, enhanced sampling, and free energy methods. This work will be performed in close collaboration with experimentalists working in the fields of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and small angle X-ray scattering, whose results will help inform, validate, and guide the development of future simulations. This project will significantly expand emerging paradigm that nucleosome functions are closely related to their conformational dynamics and provide insights into the mechanism by which nature modulates multicomponent protein/DNA systems.

Intellectual Merit: Work supported in this CAREER award has shown how dynamical properties over a wide range of time and length scales control the molecular mechanisms of epigenetic regulation.  One predominant set of epigenetic regulators are linker histones, which compact chromatin fibers and repress gene expression. This work examined the mechanisms and effects of these proteins binding to single and poly-nucleosomal structures. Results of atomic-scale simulations showed that “on-dyad” binding is enthalpically favored and significantly represses DNA motions, whereas “off-dyad” binding is entropically favored and allows for more DNA flexibility.  These results have helped resolve seemingly contradictory structural studies in which different binding modes were observed in similar environments. In a multi-scale study, this award supported all-atom and coarse-grain simulations that rigorously sample the transitions between and free energies of these states, and helped to quantify how factors such as DNA sequence and linker histone variant type influence linker histone binding. In an ambitious study of poly-nucleosomal arrays, simulations were also performed which showed that linker histone binding has large-scale effects on chromatin structures, creating more compact arrays that allow for more efficient transmission of long-range dynamics between nucleosomes. 

In another set of studies supported by this award, the PI actively collaborated with leading experimentalists to understand the chromatin structure/function relationship. With collaborators at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus, simulations and experiments focused on the structure and dynamics of the H3 N-terminal tails, a region teeming with epigenetic marks in vivo. Results from full-nucleosomes were built upon by examining tail conformations in alternative, sub-nucleosomal, structures that are composed of only four (tetramer) or six (hexamer) histones. Simulations showed that H3 tails adopt unique configurations in these states, increasing dynamics and accessibility. In another collaborative study, the PI worked with researchers at the University Colorado Boulder and Stanford University to examine how the protein CENP-N, a key kinetochore component, stabilizes inter-nucleosomal interactions for nucleosomes containing the histone variant CENP-A. Results showed that CENP-N stabilizes nucleosome stacks through specific and non-specific interactions, with effects propagating into large-scale changes in chromatin fiber structures. 

The work performed in this CAREER award produced intricate details about how structure, function, and dynamics are linked in chromatin to control gene expression.  It has also helped to lay the foundation for the PI’s independent career.  It has launched several new research directions, such as examining how epigenetic readers interact with full-length nucleosomes and the investigation of the structure/function/dynamics relationship in alternative nucleosomal structures.   

Broader Impacts:  This CAREER award supported substantial engagement by the PI to the broader community.  First, it enabled the recruitment of multiple community college students from the College of DuPage, a local community college, to perform research in the PI’s group. By working with the PI and the PI’s group members, these students gained valuable experiences in a research group that they would not be able to receive in their native institution. Many of these students have gone on to four-year programs at institutions such as Illinois Tech, Georgia Tech, and the University of Illinois, Chicago. 

Second, the proposal supported the PI’s work with members of the Academy for Urban School Leadership, National Louis University, and Illinois Tech faculty in Biology, Physics, Chemistry, and Engineering to develop and organize summer Teacher Quality Preparation workshops from 2016 through 2020. These workshops evolved in their format, but they were all hands-on activities that focused on training local K-8 teachers in effective methods for implementing the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). The PI developed several modules for these workshops ranging from a session that involved using popcorn popping to demonstrate phase transitions and model building to a session on the molecular mechanisms of drug interactions using online tools and games.  These workshops were very favorably reviewed by participants.
